title: Epiploic appendix
text:
The epiploic appendices (or appendices epiploicae, or epiploic appendages, or appendix epiploica, or <a href="greater%20omentum">omental</a> appendices) are small pouches of the <a href="peritoneum">peritoneum</a> filled with <a href="fat">fat</a> and situated along the <a href="colon%20%28anatomy%29">colon</a>, but are absent in the rectum.
They are chiefly appended to the transverse and sigmoid parts of the colon, however, their function is unknown.
The appendages can become inflamed in a painful process known as <a href="epiploic%20appendagitis">epiploic appendagitis</a> which can mimic <a href="appendicitis">acute appendicitis</a> and other conditions.
External links.
"Michael Sand et al. : <a href="http%3A//www.biomedcentral.com/content/pdf/1471-2482-7-11.pdf">Epiploic appendagitis – clinical characteristics of an uncommon surgical diagnosis</a> BMC Surgery 2007, 7:11 (1 July 2007)".
